segments.text: All right.
You mentioned win the hearts and minds.
Now, that was an official policy or strategy for you, wasn't it?
It was.
Okay.
Was it taken seriously?
And if so, how did you do it?
We would, for example, we would go into a village and we would surround it with our infantry troops.
and to prevent the B.C.
from, or the North Sea B.C.
from sneaking up and ambushing.
And then we would set up a medical dental unit inside the village, and we would do dental work and medical work for the villagers.
And, you know, those things were really effective.
On the other hand, when the B.C.
would come back in, if someone had a gold tooth, for example,
or other evidence that they collaborated with the Americans
Then they would, you know, there were reports of them being executed, being tortured, harassed, taken to relocation, you know, relocated elsewhere, those kind of things.

And, you know, once the Vietnamese perceived that we were not going to be able to protect them, that we had been in there a long time, and that our strategy of counting the numbers of bodies that we killed wasn't going to protect them in the long run,
they started to think about their own survival more than any other thing.
Okay.

Continuing with the relationship with the Vietnamese, there was a lot of talk about the U.S. Army beating stones, and probably an over-exaggeration, but to what extent was the use of narcotics, of whatever substance, especially related to your platoon and from what you saw?
I, when I was, my first assignment with Charlie Company, when I left as the acting platoon leader, I was reassigned to the mouth of 35M.
When I left the field to go to the defensive perimeter,

i expected and uh would uh would would hear and overhear people talking about it but they never took me into their confidence i just wanted to get into their confidence that uh and i could tell that some people were acting a little weirdly and uh i never
On one occasion, we were leaving for an ambush, and as I was checking the people off, my people off, at that time I had about, I was taking a couple of supplies, so I probably had about 17 people.
One of my men who was a RTO, the radio carrier, didn't have a weapon.
And I said, wait a minute, where's your weapon?
And he said, I said, if something happens,
There'll be plenty of weapons.
I'll use somebody else's weapons.
And I said, whoa, hold it right there.
Middle outer police guy said, hold it right there.
Just get back and get a weapon.
You're not going anywhere without a weapon.
This isn't, you know, come dressed as you are.
You know, everybody had to have a certain amount of, you know, had to have a weapon and so many magazines and so many grenades and signals.
You had to carry, you know, what you thought you needed.
And, uh, so at that level, uh, I, in our unit, it wasn't, uh, I wasn't aware of it being all that pervasive.
But, uh, it's, uh, probably, uh, and I'm thinking of, of marijuana.
Well, can I, how does that tie in with the, um, radio operator?
Well, I suspect that he probably had been, uh, doing some marijuana earlier.
At the time, I didn't think all that much about it.
I just thought it was kind of his somewhat absent-minded nature.
But then later on, we were ambushed, and he lost an eye.
And when I got out of my section of the hospital, I visited him, and he had said that
that he was going to stop using someone's dope.
And I assume that he'd been using dope, and I was pretty much unaware of it.
Do you know where the marijuana was bought?
Was it everywhere?
It was everywhere.
Every five-year-old kid who sold coke could either sell you or put you in contact with someone who had you buy anything you wanted.
I really don't know what the Vietnamese attitude towards prostitution was prior to us being, you know, prior to the French being, or maybe the Japanese in 39, but
It was a pretty grim survival over there, and I think that being a prostitute had a certain amount of acceptance in the way of supporting a family.
So, indirectly, do you think maybe the prevalent prostitution and the narcotics, would this maybe have been a...
and, let's say, a positive effect in the WAM, would that have won some hearts and minds?
Or maybe just as long as the bucks were flowing, they were smiling.
Do you know what I'm getting at there?
Yeah, well, if you're getting at who was in involvement with the American G.I.
to a certain segment of society,
Yeah, that element of society probably has to be the general, venerable deal that needs to be presented.
Okay.
Well, how about any...

There's been a lot of, well, let's say, with the tale of brutality on the ground and the mass long-distance and sometimes indiscriminate death from the sky, a lot of people claim that this was easily done and done because of the racist view towards the gook.
In fact, that was pretty common to call the Arvins gooks, and that is a derogatory term.
Do you agree that perhaps the whole culture, the whole people, they were looked down on?
Absolutely.

When we began the war, even through basic training and the different levels of training that the average American GI went through to get to Vietnam, they were referred to as derogatory and racist terms.
And, uh, your, uh, you know, I want to get to Vietnam, we killed some Charlie Klong.
Your airborne, uh, running song, uh, they were, they were something very, uh, racist.
And I guess there's a surveillance then in your platoon also, right?
Uh, it, it's, uh,
It was a matter of survival at that point.

And even though there was a realization that they're just like us, only on the other side, and those who aren't on the other side are in the middle, the majority of citizens, it's a matter of survival.
And I can only keep to my own right now because if I keep to somebody else's, then it'll kill me.
Well, then would you agree that there was an underlying racist attitude?
Really, no matter what was done to win the hearts and minds, it probably wasn't done with, well, with the amount of enthusiasm.
I would completely agree.
I would say that from our military strategy to the attitude that the average troop represented to the average human being,
It was a numbered game and there was no quality.
And the attitude was a very erratic attitude.
After the My Life publicity in 1968, many people argued or defended the incident by claiming the often heard grenade-rigged baby tactics employed by the VC and NBN.
Is there a certain amount of truth to that?
I think there's a great deal of truth to that.
I'm not defending the incident, but I'm saying that I know that after an extended period of combat... A little louder please.
I know that after an extended period of contact with hostile fire and friendly casualties occurring with people around you being blown to bits, being sent or killed for life,
and smiling faces turning and wheeling on you with automatic weapons, that your ability to discern between right and wrong and how to act really changes.
And it probably changes in most everything.
And you just become a little more violent and flash out.
You see, in your mind at the time, if you can eradicate these people right now that are affluent, you're not going to have the problem to live.
If you can't, you may not.
And if you're in a situation where your powers are feeling that way and thinking that way, it's hard to, it just doesn't turn off right away.
And some people are very poor judges.
Well, yeah, war is war, as some say, right?
Yes.
And that's not a justification, though.
Um, okay, well, I'd like to, I guess, hit the last thing before we call this off, and this is just pretty much your home front experience after the war.
And I'm curious, when you, okay, you returned, could you repeat again, when did you return?
I returned on July 10th, 1970.
Okay.
And, uh, that week, that was...
That was just... We had gone to Cambodia in, I believe, March.
March, April, March, yeah.
April, March, April of 1970.
And... How were you received back home?
Well, by...
I felt very disappointed because when I came into Oakland, and while I was still, before I got to the airport, I'd been insulted by, and it's called baby killer.
I'm sorry.
A what?
A baby killer.
by a long-haired hippie, who, you know, obviously had, I don't even know if he was old enough, his girlfriend was old enough to be concerned about the war, or the draft war.
And I just think I deserve that, and that just didn't make me feel very good, because I felt like I'd been lucky to escape with my life, and...
That's funny that you say that, because I've already alluded to him in his book, Rumor of War.
Philip Caputo wrote, and he was on his way returning back home, that, quote, we had done nothing more than endure.
We had survived, and that was our only victory.
Would you add to that, or does that pretty much say it?
Well, I think that pretty much says it.
All I could add to that would be to say that I think a lot of us got home
We regrouped our thoughts about what we were doing there.
And a great number of us, either we do it or we get off the pot.
Either we go in there and eradicate a great number of agents, or else we get out of there, because we are not going to win the war the way it's going.
And I think it forced a lot of us into political situations that we otherwise probably wouldn't have involved.
and has altered the course of our lives.
Why do you think there's still so many vets who are angry, unbalanced, and, well, in jail, just not getting over it?
Or is there maybe an insight to that that you could give?
I think they feel like they personally have been drained of a number of years of their life

have been gently experienced in Vietnam, and society has not responded to them in general, has not welcomed them back as people who gave everything they could for their life, and it just hasn't been too kind to the Vietnam veterans.
He doesn't recognize the Vietnam vetter for a number of years.
If you were a Vietnam vet, you would have drug-crazed Vietnam vets.
And I don't think the society has ever said, you know, you people really did a hard job.
You really did.
You know, you've been kicked in the butt by the enemy, and now you've spent a number of years spat upon by your fellow countrymen.
And you deserve that.
Okay.
I guess with the last question, it ties in with my first one, and that was of a subjective nature.
I asked you earlier, prior to NOM, what your feelings were.
And, let's see, you stated your feelings, and how did they change once you're back in, or if they had at all, what were your feelings right after, let's say, a few months in the U.S.?
Okay.
I went over there thinking that we were doing the right thing, that we were a good country, we were doing the right thing.

Once I realized that, though, entirely, we were not doing everything that we could, that the average GI was a little more than space for five houses, and that the BSC people just didn't need to be all that thrilled with us.
Uh, I was, I was disappointed on that count.
I came, came home, requested on it a while, and I eventually became, uh, involved with Vietnam better than I guess we would.
Uh, so, so...

I basically tried to assert the proposition that we were not going to win the war, that the objective that we had could not win the war, and that we should come to some other decision and more openly refuse.
I was fairly active that way.
It was a major part of my life throughout the following college years.
Then I burned out on involvement, political involvement,
I, uh, before I burned out, I was a human delegate for the EFL National Convention in Miami.
And, uh, and after working for some local candidates, uh, I haven't done anything political, really, since, uh, since about four years after returning home.
And my attitude has evolved from one of the terrible mistakes and, uh,
And people who should be listening have been ignoring, shoving it under the door, trying to point someone else to one of, in the long run, we may have served our ultimate objective.
Right now, China is in the process of capitalizing.
It looks through the example that Japan has set since World War II, the example that economic might is inferior to military might.

They look to Russia and probably don't want the average Chinese citizen to live the life that the average Russian citizen lives, and think that they can accomplish everything they want to by economic means.
I think that Vietnam would, Russia and China,
It had the effect of their parting ideological ways, and the Chinese deciding to go elect military troops.
And I think that our presence in Vietnam for the number of years, the protracted time that we were there, probably helped in the Chinese leadership at that time, that the Americans
wouldn't have been where they were for quite a period of time.
They would create enough problems that they weren't about to, that they would draw lines and not allow the Chinese to run whole hog over that section of the world.
And enough people in China probably decided that they really didn't have to fight for that.
And I'm not sure that without Vietnam, without Vietnam, there may have been more Chinese involvement in the government in Cambodia, Vietnam, Thailand, Laos.
And with Vietnam, I think it helps change the course of superpowers because China is involved in capitalizing.
Russia has a very limited, I think Russia has a limited amount of time, number of years.
They're going to have to gather so many South Americans and Africans and third world nations
to their form of government before China capitalized, because China is going to be the first example to third world peace.
And I think that because of our being involved in Vietnam, China decided, China was prevented from taking any more direct action by its more radical, early 1960s government.
And as a result, it's evolved into a somewhat more peaceful nation.
Okay.

Well, I would maybe like to sometimes catch a follow-up interview on this, even though it's not dependent on a grade, because we've touched upon a lot of things, and with some detail and then without some detail.
So for this one, thank you very
